original: Bäckström, Hans Lemmich Juel, professor, Göteborg, f. 18/12/96 i Sthlm av prof. Helge B. o. Ragnhild Juel. — Stud:ex. 14, fil. kand. i Sthlm 17, fil. lic. 22, fil. dr 27, stud. v. Univ. of Ca-lif. o. Princeton Univ. 22-24. Assist, v. Nobelinst. 25-27 o. 30-33, anst. v. Prin-ceto^n Univ. 27-30, labor. v. kontr :styr. 34, docent i fysik, kemi v. Sthlms hög-sk. 36, e. o. labor. v. Stat. inst. f. folkhälsan 41, prof. i oorg. kemi v. CTH 46, i teor. kemi 47. Uppf. det s. k. Bäckström-filtret f. isoler. av ultraviol. ljus. Skr.: The chiain reaction theory of negative catalysis (27) m. fl aVh. o. upps. isärsk. ang. kedje- o. autoxida-tionsreaktioner.
translated: Bäckström, Hans Lemmich Juel, professor, Gothenburg, born December 18, 1896 in Stockholm to professor Helge B. and Ragnhild Juel. He graduated from high school in 1914, received his Bachelor of Arts in Stockholm in 1917, his licentiate degree in 1922, and his PhD in 1927. He studied at the University of California and Princeton University from 1922 to 1924. He was an assistant at the Nobel Institute from 1925 to 1927 and again from 1930 to 1933, and was employed at Princeton University from 1927 to 1930. He worked in the contracting authority in 1934 and became a docent in physics and chemistry at Stockholm University in 1936. He was a temporary laborator at the State Institute for Public Health in 1941 and became a professor of inorganic chemistry at Chalmers University of Technology (CTH) in 1946 and a professor of theoretical chemistry in 1947. He created the so-called Bäckström filter for isolating ultraviolet light and authored numerous scientific papers and dissertations, particularly on chain and auto-oxidation reactions. He married, but his partner's name and year of marriage are not mentioned in the text.
